facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1928/67, 1274-76, 1293, 1356-57/68 were filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and orders dated 10th October 1967 and 5th February 1968 of Delhi High Court in Civil Writ Nos. 1218, 1295-97, 1320, 1344 and 1318 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the Judgment and orders dated the 10th October 1967 and 5th February 1968 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Writ Nos. 1218, 1295-97, 1320, 1344 and 1318 of 1967 respectively.

facts.text: Appellants are manufacturers of sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are manufacturers of sugar, who have companye before us after certification of their cases as fit

facts.text: Central Government issued notification dated 28-6-1967 under clause 7 of the Sugar Control Order, 1966, fixing ex-factory prices for sugar factories specified in the notification.

anchor.surface_text: They challenged the numberification dated 28-6- 1967 issued by the Central Government under clause 7 of the Sugar  Control  Order, 1966, fixing ex-factory prices for sugar factories specified

facts.text: There was an initial fixation of prices of sugar by notification dated 1-2-1967 followed by final fixation on 28-6-1967.

anchor.surface_text: the alleged failure of the Central Government to take into account the fact that there was an initial fixation of prices of sugar by a numberification dated 1-2-1967 followed by a final fixation on 28-6-1967.

facts.text: Sugar Enquiry Commission Report dated October 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Such price or maximum price shall be fixed having regard to the estimated companyt of production of sugar determined on the basis of the relevant schedule of companyt given in the Report of the Sugar Enquiry Commission  October 1965

facts.text: Appellant Saraswati Industrial Syndicate claimed Government divided country into 22 zones and put Haryana in same zone as Madhya Pradesh for conversion charges.

anchor.surface_text: The grievance of the appellant Saraswati Industrial Syndicate was that the Government had really divided the companyntry into 22 zones and that it had, while doing so, taken into companysideration the companyversion charges on the basis of five zones putting Haryana in the same zone as Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Saraswati Industrial Syndicate claimed higher wages in Haryana than Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It claimed that its efficiency as a manufacturer using modern methods was greater than that of factories in Madhya Pradesh although the wages it had to pay were higher than those paid by the Madhya Pradesh Manufacturers.

facts.text: High Court decided writ proceedings primarily on affidavits without cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: It was difficult for the High Court, as it is for us, to determine these questions of fact on the meager material or bare assertions, number subjected to cross-examination, which are available in writ proceedings decided primarily on affidavits.

facts.text: Price fixation for season 1966-67.

anchor.surface_text: We have also examined the grievance of the appellants that the price of sugar for the season 1966-67 was number determined in accordance with the relevant data.

facts.text: Sugar Enquiry Commission recommended dividing country into five zones for price fixation.

anchor.surface_text: The Sugar Commission had recommended that the companyntry should be divided into five zones for the purposes of fixation of price of sugar in each zone.

facts.text: Ex-factory price for sugar factories in Punjab including Haryana fixed at Rs. 137.35 per quintal by Notification dated 24th March 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The ex-factory price for the sugar factories in Punjab in- cluding Haryana was fixed at Rs. 137-35 per quintal by a Notification dated the 24th March, 1966.

facts.text: Ex-factory price revised to Rs. 134.55 per quintal by Notification dated 20th October 1966.

anchor.surface_text: By Notification dated the 20th October, the ex-factory price of such factories was revised to Rs. 134-55 per quintal.

facts.text: Petitioner benefited by Rs. 2.80 per quintal on deliveries from 1965-66 production up to 19th October 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, in point of fact the petitioner was benefited to the extent of Rs. 2-80 per quintal on all deliveries made from the production of the year 1965-66 up to the 19th October, 1966,

facts.text: In CA 1928/67, prices fixed were 137.75 on 1-2-1967 and 142.25 on 28-6-1967.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 1928 of 1967, prices fixed were 137-75 and 142.25 respectively.

facts.text: In CA 1356/68, price fixed on 28-6-1967 was 187.10.

facts.text: In previous year, price fixed subsequently was lower than originally fixed.

anchor.surface_text: We find that, in the previous year, the price actually fixed subsequently was lower than the price fixed originally so that various sugar producers, including, we presume, all the appellants, got the benefit of such higher prices fixed earlier.

facts.text: Union of India gave undertaking in High Court to pay balance if price found too low.

anchor.surface_text: In the Saraswati Industrial Syndicates case, there was an understanding given in the High Court by the Union of India that the Union will pay the syndicate the balance, on a redetermination of price, if the price fixed by the Government was found to be too low.

facts.text: All cases relate to season 1966-67 which was over long ago.

anchor.surface_text: All the cases before us relate to the season 1966 to 1967 which was over long ago.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant clause 7 reads as follows Power to fix sugar prices- The Central Govt. may from time to time by numberification in the Official Gazette, fix the price or the maximum price at which any sugar may be sold or delivered and different prices may be fixed for different areas or different factories or different types or grades of sugar. Such price or maximum price shall be fixed having regard to the estimated companyt of production of sugar determined on the basis of the relevant schedule of companyt given in the Report of the Sugar Enquiry Commission  October 1965 , subject to the adjustment of such rise in companyt subsequent to the Report aforesaid as, in the opinion of the Central Government, cannot be absorbed by the provision for companytingencies in the relevant schedule to that Report.

arguments.claim: Appellants should have made representations to government before court

anchor.surface_text: In any case, the appellants objections could form the subject matter of representations which could have been made to the Government by each of the parties affected.

holdings.text: The expression 'having regard to' in clause 7(2) of the Sugar Control Order, 1966 only obliges the Government to consider relevant data material but does not mandate specific adjustments or considerations beyond that.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 7(2), set out above, requires the Govt. to fix the price having regard to the estimated cost of production of sugar on the basis of the relevant schedule. The expression having regard to only obliges the Govt. to consider as relevant data material to which it must have regard  See Ryots of Garabandho and other Villages v. Zemindar of Parlakimedi Anr.  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on precedent interpreting 'having regard to' as requiring consideration, not dictation; clause provides for estimation, not compensation for prior errors.

holdings.text: There is no obligation under clause 7 to make adjustments compensating for losses due to previous price fixations.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants concede that this is the effect of language of cl. 7(2). It is evident that the price fixed is an estimated maximum price chargeable because the manufacturer cannot charge more. Furthermore, it should be noted that the only adjustment provided for is before a fixation of the estimated price having regard to the basis provided by the relevant schedule, but there is noobligation whatsoever cast upon the Government to make any adjustment to compensate for losses due to any previous erroneous fixations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of clause 7 allows 'from time to time' fixations based on estimates; adjustments for past would unfairly burden future consumers.

holdings.text: Clause 7 does not mandate division into five zones as recommended by Sugar Enquiry Commission; more zones permissible if not patently unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: One of the contentions on behalf of the petitioners was that prices should not have been determined on the basis of 22 zones but should have been determined either on an All India scale or for five zones as recommended by the Sugar Enquiry Commission. Costs of production, for purposes of price fixation, can only be determined on the basis of averages from data collected from each particular region- and conditions which affect factories in general in that region.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual obligation in clause 7; Commission's recommendation is guideline; zoning based on regional data reasonable.

holdings.text: Price fixation is legislative in nature, not quasi-judicial; rules of natural justice do not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners did not challenge the price fixation on the ground that a quasi-judicial procedure had to be adopted before prices are fixed even if such price fixation affects, as it must each factory. Price fixation is more in the nature of a legislative measure even though it may be based upon objective criteria found in a report or other material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affects class of manufacturers generally; based on objective criteria, akin to legislation.

holdings.text: Price fixation demonstrates reasonable nexus between factors considered and purpose under Essential Commodities Act; not arbitrary or in excess of power.

anchor.surface_text: Reasonableness, for purposes of judging whether there was an excess of power or an arbitrary exercise of it, is really the demonstration of a reasonable nexus between the matters which are taken into account in exercising a power and the purposes of exercise of that power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies test from precedents; Government considered relevant data like costs, recovery; no extraneous matters shown.

holdings.text: No writ of mandamus issues as no mandatory duty breached in price fixation and no prior demand and refusal made.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires proof of mandatory duty and prior demand/refusal; neither present; follows English practice under Art 226.

holdings.text: No prior demand and refusal made to Government before seeking mandamus.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants should have represented/demanded before court; none done.

holdings.text: Price fixation not ultra vires clause 7 or Essential Commodities Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No showing of excess of power, arbitrariness, or extraneous considerations.

holdings.text: Section 15 Essential Commodities Act bars suits or proceedings against Government for good faith price fixation actions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955, lays down 15(1) No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of any order made under Section 3. No suit or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Govt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provides immunity; no bad faith alleged.

holdings.text: Cost schedules in Sugar Enquiry Commission report are guidelines, not mandatory statutory provisions; Government has discretion in application.

anchor.surface_text: We have also examined the grievance of the appellants that the price of sugar for the season 1966-67 was not determined in accordance with the relevant data. As already indicated above, the cost schedules given by the Commission were only guide-lines to indicate the relevant data in fixing the price. They were not like clear mandatory Statutory provisions which could be enforced without much difficulty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elastic criteria allow inclusion/exclusion of items; not rigid.

holdings.text: Excise duty is not an item of cost of production under the schedules but considered in profits.

anchor.surface_text: For example it was suggested that excise duty was wrongly left out as an item of cost. There is nothing in the first set of schedules to indicate that excise duty must be taken into account in determining, the cost of production. In the second set of schedules excise duty is mentioned apart from manufacturing and other items of cost.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of schedules separates excise from manufacturing costs; imposed post-production.

precedents.case_name: Panipat Cooperative Sugar Mills v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonableness for judging excess of power or arbitrary exercise is demonstration of reasonable nexus between matters taken into account and purposes of the power
precedents.cited_holding: A fair price has to be determined in respect of the entire produce, ensuring to the industry a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar. But this does not mean that Government can fix any arbitrary price.

anchor.surface_text: We have also examined the grievance of the appellants that the price of sugar for the season 1966-67 was not determined in accordance with the relevant data. As already indicated above, the cost schedules given by the Commission were only guide-lines to indicate the relevant data in fixing the price. They were not like clear mandatory Statutory provisions which could be enforced without much difficulty.
Hence, their writ petitions were rightly rejected by the High Courts. As the appeals fail on merits we need number discuss the technical difficulty which an application for a writ of certiorari would

anchor.surface_text: The appellants concede that this is the effect of language of cl. 7(2). It is evident that the price fixed is an estimated maximum price chargeable because the manufacturer cannot charge more. Furthermore, it should be noted that the only adjustment provided for is before a fixation of the estimated price having regard to the basis provided by the relevant schedule, but there is noobligation whatsoever cast upon the Government to make any adjustment to compensate for losses due to any previous erroneous fixations.
Hence, their writ petitions were rightly rejected by the High Courts. As the appeals fail on merits we need number discuss the technical difficulty which an application for a writ of certiorari would

anchor.surface_text: One of the contentions on behalf of the petitioners was that prices should not have been determined on the basis of 22 zones but should have been determined either on an All India scale or for five zones as recommended by the Sugar Enquiry Commission. Costs of production, for purposes of price fixation, can only be determined on the basis of averages from data collected from each particular region- and conditions which affect factories in general in that region.
Hence, their writ petitions were rightly rejected by the High Courts. As the appeals fail on merits we need number discuss the technical difficulty which an application for a writ of certiorari would

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners did not challenge the price fixation on the ground that a quasi-judicial procedure had to be adopted before prices are fixed even if such price fixation affects, as it must each factory. Price fixation is more in the nature of a legislative measure even though it may be based upon objective criteria found in a report or other material.
Hence, their writ petitions were rightly rejected by the High Courts. As the appeals fail on merits we need number discuss the technical difficulty which an application for a writ of certiorari would
